title.rendered: The Wrong Parcel at the Right Address

content.rendered:
The Wrong Parcel at the Right Address

In the quiet, tranquil town of Neville Mr Rakesh Gupta was sitting on his old rocking chair in his garden with an album in his hand and his eyes fixed at the skies. Then he suddenly whispered, “It’s July 25th today a few weeks left for my birthday. A whole year has passed. It’s been a year since I lost you my dearest Anita, a year since I shifted here with our son John, a year since I left the country where I grew up, a year since I have started talking to myself the whole day. Of course, your son does take care of me, he takes time out to talk to me. But he too has a family to look after. But the striking resemblance of our grandson Rohan does remind me of you daily. Here I have every material possession a man my age could ask for but as you already know not all desires are earthly. I often pass my time looking at my childhood picture frames. But it’s more fun talking to you. Seems like I have bored you enough. I will go back to tending to my flowers. ”

That night his grandson looked at his frames and inquired,”Grandpa who is this man? He is present in almost every photo of your school and college’s picture frames.” To which Rakesh smilingly answered, “Son, he is your Grandpa’s best friend and so – called partner in crime. We were together from the beginning of the school till the end of our college life. And ironically his name was also Rakesh Gupta.” “You can’t be serious, both of you shared the same name,” John exclaimed with a burst of laughter. “Yes, in fact, we were a duo. We were always together in our school and college days. In fact, during our college days, a girl who liked Rakesh mistook my bag for his and placed a love letter in it. In the letter, she asked him to meet her at the café. So I went there counting my lucky stars. Isat on the table she was sitting on. We stared awkwardly like owls at each other for a good ten minutes until she finally realized the blunder she had made and broke the silence. And I can’t count the number of times I have gone to the Principal’s office listening to his share of scolding.” He said smiling sheepishly. “Well, those days have long gone in the past. Now I can only rewind those days with the support of these pictures.” John who was eavesdropping the entire conversation murmured to himself, “I achieved everything a man could ask for yet I find myself incapable of providing my father with the happiness he truly deserves. Have I failed as a son?” He sighed. Saying those words he retired to his room with guilt buried deep in his heart.

A few weeks later, Rakesh received an unexpected courier from India. At first, he was sceptical as to who could have sent it to him. But then without giving it much thought he decided to open it and found a letter on the top of the gift – wrapped courier. He opened the letter only to find the name of his friend Rakesh B. Gupta on the top of the letter. He was shocked and stared at the letter with a complete blank drawn on his face but then he decided to call his son but his phone appeared to be busy. So without giving it a great deal of thought, he decided to deliver the parcel to the correct address all by himself carrying a small ray of hope in his heart. His mind was filled with all sorts of questions and brimming with an uncontained outburst of excitement. So he rushed to the recipient’s address without a second of thought and rang the bell to his door.

His mind was a blank slate, his heart was racing, he didn’t know what to expect. To his surprise, he found his son on the front door with a joyous and expectant smile on his face. Before he could catch a breath and recollect himself he saw an old man with a welcoming smile he remembered for years. “Seems like your hair count finally matches your IQ count.” He chuckled. The face was different but the smile and the remark brought tears to his eyes as he said, “Rakesh, it’s truly you. I can’t believe my eyes.” “It’s your birthday gift dad. I know I am slightly early this time. But hey who doesn’t like advance presents.” said John. “Bless my lucky stars. I was sitting at the same café your old friend visited. And considering the number times, I have heard the tales of your endeavours it didn’t take me much time to recognize him.” He added. “You never opened the present did you Dad. Since now you know that it’s officially yours feel free to open it.” On unwrapping, he found another photo frame with an inscription, ‘To the craziness of the past and the smiles of the future.’ With a teary smile, Rakesh replied, “Thank you so much, son. I couldn’t have asked for a better present or a better son.”

Mufaddal J. Suratwala

IT 3rd SEM

content.rendered:
કહેવાય છે કે માણસ આખા જીવન દરમિયાન જે કંઈક પણ સારું નબળું કામ કરે છે, તેનું ફળ એ માણસ આ જ જીવન દરમિયાન મેળવે છે. આ વાત છે, પરિવાર અને પોતાનો કામધંધો સાચવતા એક યુવાનની. જેનું નામ હતું અર્થવ. એક વાર પરિવારના કહેવા મુજબ આ યુવાન પોતાના પરિવાર સાથે મંદિરે દર્શન કરવા માટે જાય છે. આ પર્વ હતો મહા શિવરાત્રિનો. જેના કારણે મંદિરે ખૂબ માત્રામાં ભક્તજનો શિવજીના દર્શન માટે આવ્યા હતા. અર્થવ પોતાના પરિવાર સાથે દર્શન કરવા મંદિર તરફ આગળ વધે છે. દર્શન કરવા માટે ભક્તજનોની ખૂબ લાંબી હરોળ હતી. અને આ ભીડ ઓછી થવાનું નામ ન લેતી હતી. બરાબર મંદિર પાસે પહોંચતા જ અર્થવની નજર ડાબી બાજુ બેઠેલા ભિક્ષુકો ઉપર પડી. જે પૈકીના અમુક ભિક્ષુકો વિકલાંગ હતા, એમ અર્થવે જોયું. તેઓ અર્થવ સામે હાથ ફેલાવી રહ્યા હતા. જેમની આંખોમાં ભૂખ અને પોતાના પરિવારના દુઃખની એક લાચારી સ્પષ્ટપણે અનુભવાતી હતી. પરંતુ મંદિરે માણસોની ભીડ ખૂબ વધતી જતી હતી. અર્થવ એક ઘડી માટે વિચારમાં પડી જાય છે, કે મંદિરેથી નીકળીને તેણે તરત ઑફિસે જવાનું છે. માટે સમય વ્યર્થ જાય એ જરા પણ યોગ્ય નથી. આ સમયે અર્થવ પાસે બે માર્ગ હતા. કાં તો તે ભિક્ષુકોને ભિક્ષા આપવા ત્યાં રોકાય, અથવા તો દર્શન કરવા હેતુ હરોળમાં લાગી જાય. પરંતુ અર્થવ દર્શન કરવા માટે હરોળમાં ઉભો રહી જાય છે.

       દર્શન કર્યા બાદ પરિવારથી છુટા પડી, અર્થવ ઑફિસે જવા નીકળે છે. એક મહત્વનો પ્રોજેક્ટ હાથ લેવા માટે તે ખૂબ ચિંતિત હતો. ઑફિસે તેના એક સહકર્મચારી સાથે આ પ્રોજેક્ટ મેળવવાની પ્રતિયોગીતામાં ખૂબ મહેનત કરવા છતાં પણ અર્થવ હારી જાય છે. એક નિરાશા અર્થવના મુખ ઉપર સહજ રીતે દેખાય રહી હતી. પ્રોજેક્ટ આપનારી કંપનીના ઑફિસર સામે તે પોતાનું મંતવ્ય ફરી એકવાર રજૂ કરવા ખૂબ વિનંતી કરે છે. પણ પોતાનો સમય ન બગાડતાં, તે ઑફિસર ત્યાંથી નીકળી જાય છે. અર્થવ પણ નિરાશ થઈને ઘરે જવા માટે નીકળે છે. અને પ્રોજેક્ટ ન મળવાના કારણથી એ પોતાની મહેનતને દોષ આપે છે. પોતાના બીજા કંઈક કામ માટે ઑફિસર નીકળ્યા હતા, ત્યાં રસ્તામાં તેમની ગાડી પંક્ચર થઈ ગઈ. હવે કામ ઉપર તો વહેલું પહોંચવું જ હતું! એવામાં સામેથી એક ગાડી આવી રહી હતી. ઑફિસરે મદદ માટે હાથ આગળ કર્યો. પરંતુ વાહનચાલકે ગાડી ના થંભાવી. જેથી ઑફિસર એક નિરાશામાં મુકાઈ ગયા. તેમણે ખૂબ રાહ જોઈ કે કદાચ કોઈ મારી મદદે આવે. થોડો ઘણો સમય વીતી ગયો અને એવામાં, પાછળથી એક ગાડી આવી રહી હતી. અને એ વાહનચાલક બીજું કોઈ નહિ, અર્થવ હતો. ઑફિસરને આ રીતે રસ્તે ઉભા જોઈ અર્થવે ગાડી રોકી. અને મદદ માટે પૂછ્યું. થોડા જ સમયમાં અર્થવ અને ઑફિસરે ગાડીનું પંક્ચર સુધાર્યું, અને બંને પોતાના માર્ગે આગળ વધ્યા. ઑફિસર વિચારમાં મુકાઈ ગયા કે,” પોતાનો સમય બચાવવા માટે હું પ્રોજેક્ટ બીજા કર્મચારીના હાથે સોંપી નીકળી ગયો, છતાં અર્થવે મને મારી વિકટ સ્થિતિમાં મદદ કરી. હું ખરેખર અર્થવનો આભારી છું. એક સમયે અર્થવે મારી આગળ હાથ ફેલાવવા પડ્યા, તો થોડા સમય પછી મારી પણ એ જ હાલત થઈ. ખરેખર ભગવદગીતા માં સાચું જ કહ્યું છે, કે માણસને એના કર્મનું ફળ આ જ જનમમાં મળે છે.” અને આ જ વિચાર સાથે ઑફિસર કામ માટે નીકળ્યા.

       અર્થવ ઘરે પહોંચ્યો. અર્થવના પિતાજી એક નિવૃત શિક્ષક હતા. જે હવે ઘરે બેઠા કંઈક ને કંઈક નવું કામ કરતા રહેતા હતા. આડોશ–પડોશના બાળકો આજે અર્થવના ઘરે એકત્રિત થયા હતા. અને અર્થવના પિતાજી એમને એક નાટક ભજવતાં શીખવી રહ્યા હતા. અર્થવ ત્યાં જઈને બેસી ગયો. નાટકનો સાર શું છે, એ જાણવા અર્થવે બાળકોના સંવાદ ઉપર ધ્યાન દોડાવ્યું. બાળકો વચ્ચેનો વાર્તાલાપ કંઈક આ મુજબનો હતો.

           “અવિનાશ તું ક્યારેય કોઈને નિરાશ કેમ નથી થવા દેતો? જો એમાં તારી જ ભલાઈ ના થતી હોય તો પણ?”

         “કૃણાલ, મારા પિતાજી મને હંમેશા કહેતા આવ્યા છે કે, પોતાનો સમય વ્યર્થ થતા પણ જો કોઈકની મદદ કે ભલાઈ થતી હોય, તો એ સમય વ્યર્થ નહીં, ધર્મને ફાળે જાય છે. દુનિયામાં દરેક માણસ તો કામ વગર નથી બેઠા હોતા ને! સૌથી મહત્વનું અને ઉચ્ચ સ્થાન ધરાવતું કામ એ ધર્મને અનુસરીને સારા કર્મો કરવા. જો તમે કોઈના હૃદયને હાનિ પહોંચે એવું કામ કરશો, તો એ બીજા કોઇપણ રૂપમાં કર્મ બની તમારે ભોગ લેવા આવશે જ. “

            “તો પછી ગઈકાલે મેં પેલા વાહનચાલકના છોકરાને ચોકલેટ ન આપી, એનું પરિણામ પણ મને મળશે?”

          “કૃણાલ, આજે સવારે જ્યારે આપણે બગીચામાં ગયા હતા, અને એક છોકરા એ તારી પાસેથી હિંચકો ઝુંટવી લીધો હતો, ત્યારે તું ખૂબ નિરાશ હતો. અને એ વાત તારા કર્મનું પરિણામ છે એ વાતની મને જાણ થઈ ગઈ હતી.”

           “અવિનાશ, ખરેખર આ બધી કર્મની જ રમત છે.”

         આ વાર્તાલાપ સાંભળ્યાં પછી અર્થવ તરત જ મંદિરે જવા માટે નીકળે છે. કારણકે તેને પોતાની ભૂલ સમજાઈ ગઈ હતી. મંદિરે પહોંચતા જ અર્થવ ફટાફટ ડાબી બાજુ બેઠેલા ભિક્ષુકો તરફ દોડ્યો. અને આ દરમિયાન તેનો પગ કાદવમાં પડી ગયો. આ ભિક્ષુકોમાંથી એક તરત જ દોડતો આવ્યો, અને અર્થવનો પગ સાફ કરવામાં મદદ કરી. એક કપડાંથી એનો પગ બરાબર રીતે સાફ કર્યો. અને આ જોઈ અર્થવનું મન શરમથી ભરાઈ ગયું. તેણે બેઠેલા તમામ ભિક્ષુકોને પોતાનાથી બનતી સારી એવી ભિક્ષા આપી. ભિક્ષુકોના હસતાં મુખ જોઈ અર્થવ ઘરે જવા પાછો ફર્યો.

       સંધ્યાકાળના સમયે ઘરે પાછા ફરતા અર્થવને પોતાના કર્મનો સાચો અર્થ સમજાઈ ગયો. કોઈકની પરિસ્થિતિની ક્યારેય અવગણના ન કરવી જોઈએ. અને એ જ સાચો ધર્મ છે. આજે મારો દિવસ સારો છે,કાલે ખરાબ પણ હશે. આજે હું કોઈને અવગણું છું,કાલે મારી પણ એ હાલત હશે. ખરેખર ધર્મનો નિર્વાહ કરવો જરૂરી છે. નહીં તો કર્મનો ભોગ બનવું જ પડે છે.

 

Sakshi Patel

IT 3rd SEM

excerpt.rendered: કહેવાય છે કે માણસ આખા જીવન દરમિયાન જે કંઈક પણ સારું નબળું કામ કરે છે, તેનું ફળ એ માણસ આ જ જીવન દરમિયાન મેળવે છે. આ વાત છે, પરિવાર અને પોતાનો કામધંધો સાચવતા એક યુવાનની. જેનું નામ હતું અર્થવ. એક વાર પરિવારના કહેવા મુજબ આ યુવાન પોતાના પરિવાર સાથે મંદિરે દર્શન કરવા […]

content.rendered:
હું હમણાં થોડાં દિવસ પહેલા મારા સગાસંબંધી ના ઘરે ગયો. ત્યાં રહેતા બાળકને મેં પૂછ્યું કે ,”તારે આગળ ભવિષ્યમાં શું બનવું છે અને તેના માટે તારે શું કરવાની ઈચ્છા છે?” “હું તો કલેક્ટર બનીશ.” તેને પ્રેમપૂર્વક મને જવાબ આપ્યો. હવે તે જ પ્રશ્ન મેં થોડા દિવસ પછી ફરીથી પૂછ્યો તો તેનો અલગ જવાબ હતો.બાળક જ નહિ પરંતુ આપણે પણ ઘણી વખત દ્વિધામાં હોઈએ છીએ. આપણા માંથી એવા બહુ ઓછાં વ્યક્તિ હશે કે જે પોતાની કિશોર કે યુવાની અવસ્થામાં લીધેલા ધ્યેય ને પ્રાપ્ત કરી શક્યા હશે.પોતાનો ધ્યેય સિદ્ધ કરવા વિચાર એક મજબૂત સાધન છે.પણ જો આપણો વિચાર જ મજબૂત રીતે બંધાયેલો ના હોય તો? વિચારો ની ક્ષણભંગુરતા એટલે મને આવેલો વિચાર મારા સારા માટે છે તેવું અનુભવી હું ઉત્સાહ માં આવીને થોડા દિવસ તે કાર્ય કરીશ પણ તે વિચાર પછી સ્થિર રહેતો નથી. વર્તમાન સમયમાં વિચારોની ક્ષણભંગુરતા નું સાચું ઉદાહણરૂપ એટલે ટી.વી. માં જેમ ચેનલ બદલાય તેમ આપણા માનસપટ પર એક પછી એક વિચાર બદલાતો જાય. આજે દરેક વ્યક્તિને ગંતવ્ય સ્થાને તો પહોંચવું જ છે,પણ તે વ્યક્તિ ચોક્કસ દિશા અનુસરવાનું ભૂલીને તે બીજા વિવિધ પ્રકારના માર્ગ પર અટવાઈ જાય છે. આજના યુવાનને મન પરનો કાબૂ ન હોવાથી તથા આત્મવિશ્વાસ ના અભાવે દરરોજ પોતાનો ધ્યેય બદલતો રહ્યો છે.

                                                પતંજલિ યોગશાસ્ત્ર માં કહ્યું છે કે, “षतु दीर्घकालं सत्कार सेवितो द्रधभूमि।” 

           અર્થાત્ કોઈ કાર્ય સતત અને દીર્ઘકાળ સુધી ચાલતું રહે તો જ તેનું પરિણામ મળે છે. જેમકે પાણીનું ટીપું અવિરત એક જ જગ્યાએ પથ્થર પડતું રહે તો ત્યાં કાણું પાડી શકે છે.યુવાન પોતાની કાર્યશીલતા અને મક્કમતાપૂર્વક સાધ્ય પ્રાપ્ત કરી શકે છે. આજના યુગમાં મનોરંજન અને ટેકનોલોજી ના ઉપયોગ થી યુવાનોમાં વિચારોની ક્ષણભંગુરતા થતી જોવા મળે છે.જો હું ક્રિકેટ મેચ જોવા બેસું તો તેના પ્રભાવના કારણે બીજે દિવસે મેદાન પર રમવા ચાલ્યો જાઉં.અને થોડી ક્ષણો માં મને મોટીવેશન વ્રકૃત્વ સાંભળીને બીઝનેસ કરવાની જંખના પણ જાગી જાય. અમુક સમયે તો મારા ગમતા ગાયક નું ગીત સાંભળીને તેમાં જ ખોવાયેલો રહું અને પોતાને ગાયક ની દ્રષ્ટિ એ કલ્પિત કરું છું. થોડા દિવસ પછી આપણને સમજાય કે આપણા મનમાં આવેલા ઘણાં બધાં વિચારો માંથી આપણે એક પણ સારો વિચાર ટકાવી શકતા નથી. તે વિચારને આપણે અમલમાં મૂકી શકતા નથી. યુવાની અવસ્થામાં આ પ્રકારની વૃત્તિ નો ઉદભવ સ્વાભાવિક છે પરંતુ તેનો ઉપાય પણ છે જ. આપણાં પાસે કાર્ય કરવાની અપૂરતી ઝંખનાને લીધે એકાગ્રતા માં મુશ્કેલી ઊભી થાય છે. જો આપણે આપણા વ્યક્તિ વિકાસ માટે પૂરતી લગન સાથે કાર્ય કરીને તો જરૂર ધ્યેય ને સિદ્ધ કરી શકીએ.સમાજ માં નજર નાખીએ તો એવા અમુક યુવાનો છે કે જે બાળપણ માં લીધેલો તેમનો દ્રઢ વિચાર ને વિપરીત પરિસ્થિતિમાં પણ સિદ્ધ કરી બતાવે છે. જો આપને ભૂતકાળ માં નજર નાખીએ તો દરેક સ્વતંત્ર સેનાની પોતાના એક મત અને એક વિચાર પર અડગ રહીને જીવન વિકાસ કર્યો છે. તેમના સ્થિર અને જ્વલંત કાર્ય ને લીધે આજે પણ તેઓની કીર્તિ અખંડ રહી છે.

 

Asitsinh Vaghela

IC 5th SEM

excerpt.rendered: હું હમણાં થોડાં દિવસ પહેલા મારા સગાસંબંધી ના ઘરે ગયો. ત્યાં રહેતા બાળકને મેં પૂછ્યું કે ,”તારે આગળ ભવિષ્યમાં શું બનવું છે અને તેના માટે તારે શું કરવાની ઈચ્છા છે?” “હું તો કલેક્ટર બનીશ.” તેને પ્રેમપૂર્વક મને જવાબ આપ્યો. હવે તે જ પ્રશ્ન મેં થોડા દિવસ પછી ફરીથી પૂછ્યો તો તેનો […]

title.rendered: New Model for predicting solar flares

content.rendered:
Most of us are generally unaware of the term Solar flares. Actually, a solar flare is a sudden flash of brightness on the sun, usually observed near its surface and in close proximity to a sunspot group. They aren’t a direct threat to humans as the earth’s atmosphere protects us from the radiation of space weather. But if an astronaut out in space is bombarded because of a solar storm he or she might be killed. Another example is from the movie Mission Mangal. Our rocket faced a solar storm which in turn in creased its speed. 


Scientists have developed a new model that successfully predicted seven of the Sun’s biggest flares from the last solar cycle, out of a set of nine. With more development, the model could be used to one day inform forecasts of these intense bursts of solar radiation. 


As it progresses through its natural 11-year cycle, the Sun transitions from periods of high to low activity, and back to high again. Generally, most of us focus on the most dangerous part of the task in order to survive or get through. Similarly, scientists focused on X-class flares, the most powerful kind of these solar fireworks. Compared to smaller flares, big flares like these are relatively infrequent; in the last solar cycle, there were around 50. But they can have big impacts, from disrupting radio communications and power grid operations, too–at their most severe–endangering astronauts in the path of harsh solar radiation. Scientists who work on modeling flares hope that one day their efforts can help mitigate these effects. 


Led by Kanya Kusano, the director of the Institute for Space-Earth Environmental Research at Japan’s Nagoya University, a team of scientists built their model on a kind of magnetic map: SDO’s observations of magnetic fields on the Sun’s surface. Their results were published in Science on July 30, 2020. Solar flares are a sudden explosion of energy caused by tangling, crossing, or reorganizing of magnetic field lines near sunspots. The surface of the Sun is a very busy place. It has electrically charged gases that generate areas of powerful magnetic forces. These areas are called magnetic fields. 


Kusano and his team looked at the seven active regions from the last solar cycle that produced the strongest flares on the Earth-facing side of the Sun (they also focused on flares from part of the Sun that is closest to Earth, where magnetic field observations are best). SDO’s observations of the active regions helped them locate the right magnetic boundaries, and calculate instabilities in the hot spots. In the end, their model predicted seven out of nine total flares, with three false positives. The two that the model didn’t account for, Kusano explained, were exceptions to the rest: Unlike the others, the active region they exploded from was much larger and didn’t produce a coronal mass ejection along with the flare.

Gautam Gandhi

IT sem 3

They aren’t a direct threat to humans as the earth’s atmosphere protects us from the radiation of space […]

content.rendered:
Several times a day we become completely detached from our surroundings and get lost deep in the recesses of our mind. Be it during a lecture or a long shower, falling into the pit of our thoughts is inevitable. It’s remarkable, how we lose all consciousness when we are day-dreaming. No conversation could compare to the ones we have with ourselves.

We all have a unique way of communicating with ourselves. More precisely, we all have a language we do our thinking in. For most people, it is their native language. But not all thoughts have a language. Our brain has a lot of signals. From your lively smile to the tell-tale tears. From the bursting veins when you are furious, to the Goosebumps when you are nervous. Our brain informs us of our thoughts in several ways.

Have you ever wondered, what must new-borns think? Babies think all the time. Constantly absorbing information from everything that exists, and processing it. But they know no language. So what is the syntax of their thoughts? Just the thought of what goes in their tiny little heads baffles me. Their array of thoughts could be in the form of a diverse network, forming strategic links with each other, a process too complex to comprehend. Or the thoughts could be random signals that guide them. Their thoughts could never be put into words, because there are no words there!

These ‘language-less’ thoughts must have a pattern of their own too. The ‘Language of Thought Hypothesis (LOTH)’ describes thought process as a language which has grammar of its own. The hypothesis says that the brain follows simple rules which combine in various ways to build thoughts. But are thoughts so mathematical? How can something be so random and yet so symmetrical? Why have I taken for granted, this mysterious entity for so long? We are centuries away from understanding the human brain completely. And while there might be some truth to LOTH, the mechanism of thoughts shall remain shrouded in mystery as long as our brain is.

At this day of age, we know so much about ourselves, and yet we have barely scratched the surface. When we would have finally figured it all out, I believe that’s when we will reach the peak of discoveries. Or will we?

Khadija Sidhpuri

CE 5th Sem

content.rendered:
Hello!
It’s me, an unread message.

You might not know me since I am (literally) unread. Have you ever heard of an introvert getting ignored on a daily basis? Yeah, I’m the same species. I think, a problem well stated is a problem half solved. So here I present some irrefutable facts.

My existence can be in any form. I could either be your tenant reminding you to pay the rent, or your boss inquiring about your absence, or your annoying girlfriend wishing you a good morning or even a bank offer with terms and conditions. My lifespan can be in the range of two days to forever. One time, my fellow receiver, who happened to be a mom ignored a text from her kid saying “Mom, Rhea burnt the garden down” for three hours. But it’s not her fault I guess. Maybe she thought it was a prank. Had it been a voice call, the kid might’ve howled, sending the mother rushing towards the precious greens. Hence why, in a world full of superfluous gifs, jpegs and voice mails, I am an omnipresent yet a crass form of media.

I have quite a miserable life really. It’s as if the receiver greets me with “I’m really sorry I didn’t say hi, make eye contact or acknowledge your presence in any way when you waved at me in the hallway the other day. It’s nothing personal. I just have too many people trying to greet me these days, and I can’t respond to everyone.” But at least it’s better than “I’m too busy to answer your email, your email is not a priority for me right now.”

And how do you know if a message you’ve received doesn’t deserve a response anyway? My friend “Notification” here, is terrific! He tells people, rather notifies them and even states the message in brief. Like a title to an essay. Buddy if you’re reading this, I’m quite upset okay?

The other day, we had this casual meet when the phone ran out of battery. Mr Gif said that he is really praised by the users. Mute, yet subtle. And we discussed about how people get excited about images and videos that they leave their assigned work and scurry off to open the chat. Even in math class! Miss facetime is the most celebrated media of all. Everyone just wishes to be like her.

But sometimes I feel I’m liked by the person not reading me. It could be a student avoiding an email of exam results, or a message from dad asking to call back as soon as possible, or an editor trying to avoid a deadline. Like yesterday, this fellow avoided a text saying, “bro plz pick me up 2morrow.” Yes, I know the English drives people up the wall, but the poor guy wanted a ride. But I guess it’s just a matter of priorities. He ignored the text and I felt I was appreciated at that time.

But hey! At least I’m not ignored as much as the warnings after compiling a program.

Anyway, I’ll get going. I have to reside in someone’s chat.

Yours truly,
A message.
(hopefully read)

Priya Rathod

IT 5th SEM

content.rendered:
Vintage, cottagecore, dark academia, pastel. Wait, this isn’t another story about good old school times. These are just a few words that would be appropriate for my “aesthetic” or, for the layman, the way I integrate my visual preferences like color palettes, and themes in my everyday life. Let me clear this out as well, it isn’t just about the visual appeal, but aesthetics are in themselves a lifestyle. As cliché as it sounds, they let you shape your preferences and guide your decisions. For me, it is just a methodical approach to ground my hedonistic desires, and at the same time let me discover my individuality.

It is quite a privilege to be able to have multiple miscellaneous objects at your disposal, and to be able to choose from them, so why not make the most of what we have? Why not express our inner self ever so subtly yet so loudly with everyday commodities? My aesthetic revolves around that of my phone. Even though that one object, in particular, is capable of expressing a thousand things, I try to add a little more to every new addition to my collection.

For starters, my phone came in a glossy green finish. Too flashy for some people, but perfect for me. To be honest, I am more of a blue person, but this time green appealed to me more. After choosing it, I decided to dig up what green stands for. I started with our Tiranga and found that green stands for fertility and growth. That fit quite well, considering that I was getting through a new phase in my life altogether. I was growing up for real, so to say. Since I am a believer in the roots of Vedic literature, I found that it also stands for the heart chakra, Anahata. Again, this was relevant to considering that I was following my heart and stepping into the world of medicine.

However, this just wasn’t enough for me. I have always loved blue. When I was a child, one of the most common things grown – ups used to ask me was my favorite color, and why, and I always used to say sky blue, because the sky has no limits. They shrugged it off because it was a common reply, but little did they know how much it would go on to shape my personality. How I would hate being constrained and stopping because it had been “enough”. These are pretty aggressive and antisocial qualities to have, but when there’s kindness and passion and wisdom in this equation, it becomes a perfect recipe. And blue binds it all together, the vastness of the sky, the depth of seas, and quenching of thirst. It is my childhood, the essence around which “me” as a person has been wrapped around in layers by my experiences and time. Hence, it was an unavoidable addition in the form of a case. It is a liquid marble case with various shades of blue, further strengthening the need for fluidity and inclusivity. Since the lockdown gave too much free time, I spun up some old colors with glitter and painted my black watch to suit my phone; green with speckles of blue.

My aesthetics don’t end here, rather they’ve just begun. I added a sticker of an owl at the phone grip, for its symbolic value. An owl firstly has a vision in the night, and that is extremely necessary in this ruthless world. Foresight is not a gift, it’s a necessity. Secondly, in Hindu mythology, an owl is the vehicle of Goddess Lakshmi, the goddess of wealth, fortune, and success. My preference for this point wasn’t in hopes of supernaturally receiving wealth, but instead because of the stealth and dexterity, since Goddess Lakshmi is known to be very agile. Lastly, the owl is the symbol of Goddess Athena in Greek mythology, who is the goddess of wisdom and intellect. As an offering to these gods, I wanted something simple yet ancient, obvious but covered in layers, and there it was.

I could go on about my wool braided earphones and a simple silver earring, bu t that would be boring. The point of this article is to incite that spark in you that seeks to be seen while being hidden, in plain sight; the spark dripping with individuality that has been absorbed from various cultures, and to create an environment that fills you with joy, and satisfaction, to create your own aesthetic.

Dhruv Pathak

1st Year MBBS

These are just a few words that would be appropriate for my “aesthetic” or, for the layman, the way I integrate my visual preferences like color palettes, and themes in my everyday life. Let me clear this out as well, […]

content.rendered:
The trouble being early is no-one there to appreciate it. Planning out about any task looks great on paper. Even though, I try to strive for something tremendous it happens to be accomplished by the end of the deadline. Even if I am given 4 months break to complete a task I would perch on the last day and would start my task. I could work very efficiently in the burden. my trait gave me contentment. I was never sure that by grabbing pride in such a vague habit, what I had been trying to demonstrate? Rather most importantly to whom. In this developing competitive world, this trait is referred to as a sense of irresponsibility.

The world of innovative ideas always opens up for me a few hours before my deadlines. No-one encouraged me and none could understand my perception, I was repeatedly told that the task is given never changes on the first day of submission as well as on the last day of submission. As time flew I was accustomed to all those cold scathing remarks. That consistently said you are brilliant enough and capable enough to finish off your work before time and set up as an example for others. But being sluggish ruins it all! There was a deep physiological fact related to it that is first you admire the person for who you are and then you say with some modification you would be at your best. The main question is why should I change? My mom and my school faculties had dealt with me the same way. You know when a mommy decides to accomplish a task no-one would think about messing up with her in her agendas.

My mom was way too clever wherever I use t o write my deadlines for the specific task she would erase it off and write a date 2-3 days ahead of the date provided. This strategy was a success until pre-school after that I avoided jotting down deadline. Still, all the wisdom of being “on-time” was bestowed upon me year after year. All the undertakings were futile. Several instants I have even felt that working on last-minute, no doubt gives rise to innovative opinions. Many times make me feel overwrought, and even during those last moments of my submission, I would ponder what I was doing, up all the time. And ended up criticizing my inner self that minding so much arrogance was not reasonable for me. Amidst all these “Postpone” is elation to my spirit. If things get postponed then my speed of work also gets halted. As it is said that a dupe always learns from his own experience and a rational man learns from others’ experiences. An extraordinary lesson was waiting for me.

I recollect one such instance where we were facing a power cut. I remember it so vividly that this date my mom makes fun of that. Actually, I had forgotten to pay the electricity bill in spite of given hundreds of reminders by my Mum, Dad, and Google Calendar. Regardless of my habit to put off things for the Last Date. It just slipped through my mind. The following day we were having a test at school and to this date, my mother has still kept my answer sheet. It appears to be a token where finally I comprehended that it was high time to get disconnected with the deadlines. Soon I began thinking that maybe it’s high time now and some serious modifications need to be uploaded on my Life Drive. Oops, I just forgot I have an assignment due tomorrow.

Muskan Vora

EC 3rd SEM

excerpt.rendered: The trouble being early is no-one there to appreciate it. Planning out about any task looks great on paper. Even though, I try to strive for something tremendous it happens to be accomplished by the end of the deadline. Even if I am given 4 months break to complete a task I would perch on […]

title.rendered: An Open Letter to Kishore Kumar

content.rendered:
Dear Kishore da,

As far as I can remember, I have woken up from my afternoon naps with Bollywood classic songs playing on our television. This raw and perpetual exposure at a young age was one of the perks of being the daughter of a music fanatic. Every void in the day was filled with music, be it the upbeat remixes, melancholy blues or melodious romantics. Growing up in such a place makes one feel connected to music and singers in ways nothing else does. And I was lucky enough to feel this connection with you Kishore da. I have to thank you for the plethora of genres you wrote and sang for that now each of my moods has a great song to fall back on. It isn’t just your beautiful voice that has captured my heart but also the meaningful lyrics in most of them. All your songs take us through a journey and show us vivid images in a short span of 5 minutes. The benchmark you have set in playback singing hasn’t even be touched by anyone since you left us. It was because of your songs like khaike paan banaras wala, aanewala pal and pyaar diwana hota hai that made me watch their movies and introduced the world of classics to me. Of course, not all the movies you sang for were as entertaining. I can name a ton of movies with brilliant songs but crap plots.

During one of my binge-watching sessions, I came across Padosan, and I was pleasantly surprised to see my favorite singer playing a role in it. It was amusing to watch a pan chewing ustad going to great lengths so that his friend could woo the girl in samne wali khidki. I remember rolling on the floor, laughing to my hearts’ content during the sing-off in song ek chatur naar karke sringar. This was the moment I started seeing you in a new light. I had assumed that playback singers and lyricist had an air of seriousness around them and wouldn’t like being a laughing-stock. But here you were playing the role of a comedian with ease. When I discussed this with my parents, they simply laughed and showed me a list of movies where you played a comic role. Apparently, you were well-known for your comedy movies. This was the moment when your mechanic’s role in ek ladki bheegi bhagi si made sense to me. 

As if this new-found knowledge wasn’t enough that you surprised me again with your quirky habits. I was casually watching a news channel one day when a short 20 minutes long tribute for you came up. It said a bit about your eccentric behaviors. If I am not wrong didn’t you have a ‘Beware of Kishore’ sign outside your Warden road flat? One of the many questions I wanted to ask you was, why were you so paranoid about being paid. I mean going to the extent of shaving just a side of your face before a scene since you were only paid half the promised amount is unheard-of. People say that as you grew older your dislike towards everyone in general increased. I find that extremely hard to believe. How can someone who appears so friendly on-screen and who has sung so many jovial songs be a loner? Was this the reason behind marrying 4 times? Only you can answer this question Kishore da.

Your ability to yodel perfectly, diverting to a nonsense rhyme and coming back to the original tune is exhilarating. And I hope it makes you happy to know that even now your songs are just as appreciated and your fan base has increased manifolds. There have been many singers who have tried copying your style and made remixes of your songs. But none of them have been able to deliver what you could. I always thought that one requires to be professionally trained in singing to become a playback singer but you broke the stereotype. Personally, I love those songs in which you collaborated with Rajesh Khanna, Lata Mangeshkar, and the Burmans. Your sudden death took everyone by surprise and left an ever-existing void in the music industry. But I hope that you are in a place jahan gham bhi na hoo aansun bhi na ho bas pyar hi pyar pale.

Yours sincerely,

Ek ajnabee haseena

Divyashree Iyer

IT 5th Sem

excerpt.rendered: Dear Kishore da, As far as I can remember, I have woken up from my afternoon naps with Bollywood classic songs playing on our television. This raw and perpetual exposure at a young age was one of the perks of being the daughter of a music fanatic. Every void in the day was filled with […]

content.rendered:
The sound of Kathakali mushroomed over the silence of encompassing night. Adityan, holding a coconut stepped into the temple. Inside, everything was yellow coloured and everything smelled of recent rain. He went straight to the kuthambalam were his favourite play Kathakali was being performed.

It didn’t matter to him that the Kathakali had begun hours before he came. For him, they were as familiar as the house he lived in. The plays didn’t surprise him with the unforeseen. Adityan sat there with his back against a white pillar. On the stage he watched a man playing the role of Karna, the great and generous warrior. Adityan thought to himself ‘Karna’s oath’ and smiled at his own intelligence of remembering the name of the part being performed from his childhood. Karna, the desolate son of Sun, the abandoned child was praying near the banks of the Ganga. It was the scene just before the great Mahabharata yudh(war).

Then the red-eyed Kunti appeared. The role of Kunti was too performed by a man but with ample bosoms. She had come to tell Karna a story. She told him about a young beautiful woman who had been gifted a boon. A mantra, that she could choose a lover from the gods. To test if it really worked, she went to an empty field in the morning. Closing both the eyes and facing the clear blue sky, she recited the mantra. When she opened her eyes, she saw the Lord Sun, the god of the day himself appeared before her. Charmed by the beauty of shimmering God, she gave herself to him. Nine months later, she had a son. Kunti said the young woman loved her son more than anything that existed for her but her fate had other plans. She couldn’t keep him as she was unmarried. So she put him in a basket and cast him away in a river.

The child was then found by a charioteer who named him Karna. Karna who listened the whole story cautiously, asked Kunti with tears in his eyes, “Who was she? Take me to her. I want to meet my mother.” An ashamed Kunti bowed down to him and said, “she’s standing just before you.” Karna’s emotion was heightened. He was both angry and delighted to find his original mother after decades. He asked her, “where were you all this time? Did you ever hold me? Did you ever feed me? Did you ever think of me? Did you ever look for me? Did you ever wonder where I might be?”

Adityan who was still sitting under the white pillar was familiar with these questions. Not because kathakali was saved to his memory but because his life greatly depended on these questions. He lived each day by asking these questions to himself. Adityan, the generous kiddo just like Karna grew up without his mother in an orphanage. But the only difference was that Adityan knew who his mother was from his childhood. Adityan knew that he was an illegitimate son. He knew his mother too couldn’t keep him because she was unmarried when she had him. He knew that his mother was then married. He knew she had other children. Two Sons. More beloved sons- Adityan always believed.

On the stage Kunti wailed to her son to make a promise. She wanted him to abandon the Mahabharata yudh as he would be fighting his own blood. His younger brothers. The Pandavas. More beloved sons. Karna couldn’t make this promise as he would have to revoke another one made to Duryodhana. Karna always hated Arjuna, the eldest among Pandavas but not the eldest among Kunti’s sons. He was the one who publicly criticized him for being a low charioteer’s son. He hated Arjuna. But on the other hand, he could not refuse his mother. So he made an adjustment. He said, “Yudhistira I won’t harm, Bhima I won’t kill, Nakula and Sahadeva I won’t touch. But Arjuna I won’t spare.”

Adityan put his head between his two folded knees and sat there. He remembered how his mother used to ignore him in public but would shower all her love when she came to orphanage to visit him. He remembered her beautiful smile. The most beautiful smile he thought. But Adityan never talked to her. Not a single time. Because he always hated her for making him live a lone life. One without anyone to look after.

Adityan remembered the last time she came to visit. She had said, “Adi, you are a smart young boy. Always remember I love you in same way I love your younger brothers. Please talk to me for once.” Just like every other time, Adityan ignored her. And then days later he came to know he would never be able to talk to her or for that matter never see her. A car accident made all the difference.

Sruthi Cheruvullil

EC 5th SEM

Inside, everything was yellow coloured and everything smelled of recent rain. He went straight to the kuthambalam were his favourite play Kathakali was being performed. It didn’t matter to him that the Kathakali had begun hours […]

content.rendered:
What if someone told you that all the electronic circuits, Integrated circuits and chips that use extended wires and technologies like CMOS, FinFets, etcetra could possibly go obsolete in the near future?
How would you like a soft, circuit-free robot driven entirely using the light of the sun? Researchers from the Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences(SEAS), in collaboration with researchers at McMaster University and University of Pittsburgh, have developed a new platform for all-optical computing, which could replace these electronics.

Present world computation uses hard materials or hardware like metal wires, semiconductors and photo diodes to couple electronics to light. Using the all-optical computing technology, it would be possible to remove the rigid components and control computations solely with beams of light.

To control light with light, researchers decided to use non-linear materials that change their refractive index in response to the intensity of light. When light is shone onto these materials, their refractive index increases, generating their own, light-made waveguide. However, the current technology limited the use of non-linear materials as they required high-powered laser lights or else they would be changed by the transmission of light.

Therefore, researchers developed a completely new material that uses reversible swelling and contracting in a hydrogel under low laser power to change the refractive index. The hydrogel is composed of a polymer network that swells with water, like a sponge, and a small number of light-responsive molecules known as spiropyran; molecules similar to those being used in tint transition lenses. When the gel is illuminated, the area under the light contracts making the polymer dense and in turn changing the refractive index. When the light is removed, the gel recovers its original shape. So when light beams are shone through the material, any two different beams behave as inputs to an optical gate. As an example, Beam A could inhibit Beam B, Beam B could inhibit Beam A, both could cancel each other out or both could go through.

“Though they are separated, the beams still see each other and change as a result,” says Kalaichelvi Saravanamuttu, an associate professor of Chemistry and Chemical Biology at McMaster and co-senior author of the study. “We can imagine, in the long term, designing computing operations using this intelligent responsiveness.”

“Not only can we design photoresponsive materials that reversibly switch their optical, chemical and physical properties in the presence of light, but we can use those changes to create channels of light, or self-trapped beams, that can guide and manipulate light,” says co-author Derek Morim, a graduate student in Saravanamuttu’s lab.

This reversibly responsive material that controls light at exceptionally small intensities holds a promising future and perhaps a technological revolution in the field of materials science.

Snigdha Lokre

EC 5th SEM

How would you like a soft, circuit-free robot driven entirely using the light of the sun? Researchers from the Harvard John A. Paulson […]

content.rendered:
The 21st century is an era of an uncurbed outburst of technological advancements. Artificial intelligence to robotics, renewable energy resources to environment conservation, material engineering to nanotechnology are just a few of the endless technologies of the current era. However, amongst all these, nanotechnology is pivot in the development of all other technologies. Nanotechnology is the manipulation of matter at atomic, molecular and supramolecular scale. As a rule, the most important need in the field of nanoscience is binding atoms and molecules together and more importantly doing it in a controlled manner. However, can a particle bind materials at the atomic scale? Additionally, can it control the bound particles at a constant rate? All these questions lead to one answer and that is “Nanocellulose.”

Recently, researchers from Aalto University, Germany, discovered a unique cohesive property of nanocellulose of binding particles in a constant and controlled manner. But exactly what are Nanocellulose? Nanocellulose are tiny fibrils extracted from plants and recently they have been getting a lot of attention for their strength. In the opinion of the scientists, these minuscule materials have shown a lot of promise in outperforming plastics and even replacing them. On the other hand, the most perplexing fact about them is that they have shown strong binding properties to form new materials with any particle.

The first struggle for any researcher who wants to create materials is to come up with a way to generate cohesion which in turn is extremely particle dependent. Fortunately, nanocellulose has helped them overcome that struggle, as it can overcome any particle dependency. Nanocellulose possesses the ability to form networks at the nanoscale that adapt according to the given particle.

Nanocellulose bind the particles by forming sheet-like structures and also form tiny fishnets to trap smaller particles like nanoparticles. Moreover using them, materials can be moulded into any shape by an extremely simple and spontaneous process that needs only water. Interestingly, they form such networks by following extremely precise scaling laws which make their implementation way easier.

These developments are extremely timely in the field of nanotechnology, wherein combining nanoparticles with bulk materials is of prime necessity. According to researchers, nanocellulose has become a bridge joining laboratory discoveries with current manufacturing techniques. The researchers claim that they will now be able to produce materials from particles ranging from 20-20,000 nanometers in diameter. Moreover, inert particles such as metallic nanoparticles to microorganisms such as baker’s yeast can be compounded, given a different shape from 1D to 3 D and can be converted to hydrophilic or hydrophobic forms. In conclusion, their team leader, Prof. Orlando Rojas, said, ‘This is a powerful and generic method, a new alternative that bridges colloidal science, material development and manufacturing’.

Mufaddal Suratwala

IT 3rd SEM

Artificial intelligence to robotics, renewable energy resources to environment conservation, material engineering to nanotechnology are just a few of the endless technologies of the current era. However, amongst all these, nanotechnology is pivot in the development of all other technologies. Nanotechnology is […]

content.rendered:
Dear Ranveer Allahabadia AKA Beerbiceps, co-founder of monk-entertainment and the creator of India’s top podcast channel TRS (The Ranveer show) with over 2 million subscribers on both YouTube channels. I was in 9th grade when I came across a YouTube channel owned by an engineering student and a fitness coach who was working hard to become a successful entrepreneur. I am grateful to have known you this early.

Just like you and millions out there, Dragonball Z is my favourite anime. You said in one of your podcasts that Dragon ball Z depicts that life is all about breaking the existing limits and evolving throughout our lives in all aspects like speed, strength and intellect. It is a great lesson for us, who want to strive greatness no matter what comes up in our way of success. Life is all about breaking the limits and evolving into a smarter, stronger and a better person.

I connect with you, cause just like you even I went through the dark days of IIT coaching for a year. Solving dozens of questions, completing assignments, weekly test and the unceasing feeling you get that there are lakhs of students out there, who are better than you haunts one down. But the whole experience gave me a lot of lessons that will always remain in my life. I didn’t crack IIT but the competitive atmosphere got me into thinking that if in life I will not work hard then there are millions out there who are dreaming the same dream which I am dreaming. So, if you want to achieve what you dream, you need to work harder, smarter, faster each day till you get what you want. Determination is everything.

In one of your podcasts (TRS-E8), you said, “My teacher always used to look down on me.”. I think being a backbencher in my school and college I can say that they look down on average, below-average students a lot. They are very fearful of the change, sometimes they say things which can shatter a student’s heart.
“IF YOU DONT GET A GOOD JOB, YOUR CAREER IS OVER!”.
My math teacher told me 2 weeks before my board exam that she doesn’t think that I can pass my board exams. Hearing this type of declarations by your teacher just two weeks before the paper can terribly affect your mindset, confidence and most importantly the belief you have in yourself. Some teachers even told me how scoring in school decides a lot about your future. They have gone through this phase and they have followed the traditional method of going to school, having a degree, ending with a job and go on paying the bills.
At that tender age when we don’t know much about life, we tend to believe that our percentage decides our fate. But it’s not like that, we are living in an era where there is an abundance of opportunity. What we really need is a desire to do something backed with insatiable faith in our desire. No one can stop you after that. Literally no one.

I learnt one thing very early that no matter how great you are doing there will always be someone who will try to pull you down. You must focus your mind on the positive aspects of life rather than worrying on negative comments but at the same time, we should try to learn from our mistakes. You are the only sensible influencer who can talk about anxiety, depression low self-esteem with so much clarity. The way you are trying to spread the knowledge about all this is simply commendable.

Your take on Yoga and meditation is like a modern-day saint. I was also very sceptic about all this but your videos have changed my perspective completely. Meditation is literally the art of doing nothing at all. Sitting comfortably for 10 minutes alone can solve most of your problems. We are so busy in our routine that sometimes we tend to suppress our negative thoughts instead of thinking about it. Letting your negative thoughts go is the first step towards self-control. Your mind is that weapon which can either destroy your problems or it can create your problems. The choice is yours. The essential point of understanding the mind is that liberation from suffering cannot be found outside the mind. Your mind has the questions of life and the answers of life both. You just need to find them!

You are an apostle of positivity. Your videos, podcasts and your actions are inspiring a lot of young kids. Keep sharing, inspiring and fueling the youth with positive energy!

From,
A small boy with many dreams.

Pruthvirajsinh Gohil

MH 3rd Sem

I was in 9th grade when I came across a YouTube channel owned by an engineering student and a fitness coach who was working hard to […]

content.rendered:
Two majestic mahogany doors lead me into a hall lit with numerous incandescent light bulbs. The room is filled with my guests. The sight of such pristine individuals makes goosebumps to crawl up my arms. My humongous hall seems to narrow down as the chitter-chatter grows louder with each of my steps forward.

Against the vintage wallpaper, a lady’s diamond crown stands out. The air around her smells of success and poise. My long-gone adolescent self leaves me with a burnt mark as she tries to push through my chest only to cower back in, ones under the iridescent shadow of the pageant queen. Tearing my eyes away from her I push my way further into the hall.

Some of my guests show signs of familiarity in meeting my gaze. My whole being starts to perish gradually as I remember the reason behind sending them an invitation. Hazy visions of sitting in a lonely park swing clutching my Math paper filled with red marks and the salty taste of tears on my chapped lips cross my mind. The vision is replaced with that of a classroom where the younger version of one of my guests smiles proudly as she walks towards her seat with a chorus of resounding claps from our peers and teacher. A wave of bitter nostalgia hits me as memories of my guests outperforming me in all phases of life comes crashing down on my fragile self. My shoulders droop down as the burden of self-loathing doubles up. Turning my sneering face away, I take heavy steps further into the abyss of my insecurities.

The presence of these accomplished individuals reignites the green flame in my heart. Shadows of my elders start manifesting out of thin air. I jerk up a bit as these shadows mummer old saying and quotes from the Holy Book in my ears while floating around me. I push past those Holy words and near my inevitable destruction. As malice starts clouding my eyes my throat turns dry and a revolting taste fills my mouth. I succumb to my evil intentions and growl at my guest. I try to claw out their intelligence and beauty, their benevolence and strength and rub it harshly on my skin, trying to merge it in my meagre self, desperately hoping for a miracle.

The marble floor beneath me shakes violently as my actions worsen. My insides churn and my core burns up as the cloud of disappointment around my elders grows larger. A pungent odour fills my hall. Fear creeps up as my beautiful walls start to crumble down. I try to crawl away but the burden of decade’s worth of self-loathing and malevolence halts me as I wait for my imminent demise.


Invidia is one of the Seven Deadly Sins in Christian belief. It is the Latin word for Envy. Invidia is shown as a Roman goddess to personify Envy. She is drawn with a serpent coiled around her breast and biting her heart, to signify “she was herself her torment”.

Divyashree Iyer

IT 5th Sem
